cds.java.project.concurrent

Class ConcurrentQueue<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • cds.java.project.concurrent.ConcurrentQueue<T>

  • public class ConcurrentQueue<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    A particular implementation of a first in / first out (FIFO) queue that works correctly in a situation in which multiple threads try to access it at the same time, either for adding new values or for removing already added ones Two methods have been implemented, the enq(), for adding a new value at the end (tail) of the queue and the deq(), for removing the first element (head) of the queue This is a generic class, meaning that the "T" value can be replaced with an Integer, String, Character, RandomCharacter (and so on) instance
    Since:
    2018-12-31
    Author:
    Buse-Dragomir Alexandru

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private int head
      The current head of our concurrent queue The volatile keyword guarantees that any thread that reads this member will see the most recently written value
      private java.util.concurrent.locks.Condition queueCondition
      A condition variable belonging to the reentrant lock, used in order to perform await(), signal(), signalAll and so on, operations used in order to ensure that we manage with the cases in which the queue is either empty or full
      private java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock queueLock
      An instance of the ReentrantLock -implementation of the Lock interface-, the queueLock is fundamental in ensuring the synchronization of the queue operations performed by the producers and consumers threads
      private int queueMaxSize
      A member which holds the maximum length of the queue, so the number of elements that can fit inside the queue until it is full
      private T[] queueValues
      The generic array that is the actual concurrent queue in which all operations will be performed (values added and then consumed)
      private int tail
      The current tail of our concurrent queue The volatile keyword guarantees that any thread that reads this member will see the most recently written value

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      ConcurrentQueue(int queueMaxSize)
      The constructor gets the maximum dimension of the queue; it initialises the head and the tail as being 0, so no element is present in the queue in this moment It creates a new reentrant lock instance and uses its newCondition() method in order to obtain a condition variable; we create a generic queue that will hold a maximum number of queueMaxSize elements; created as an array of Object instances, it is then casted to the generic type T

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      T[] getQueueValues()
      A getter method that returns the inner queue used in order to modelate the ConcurrentQueue class
      private boolean isQueueEmpty()
      A simple boolean method that checks if the queue is empty, by verifying if the tail is equal with the head (meaining that there are no elements left) if it is not the case, the method returns false
      private boolean isQueueFull()
      A simple boolean method that checks if the queue is full, by verifying if the difference between the tail and the head is equal with the maximum capacity of our queue; if it is not the case, the method returns false
      T popFromConcurrentQueue()
      A method that removes a value from the head of the queue At first, it tries to acquire the lock; if it succeeds, it tries the following: if the queue is empty and no elements can be removed at the moment, it awaits in a while loop; once it gets past the while loop (there is at least a value in the queue), it calculates the position of the first element (the head index) and then removes it form the queue, increasing afterwards the value of the head so that it indicates now to the next position in which the first valid element can be found A message is printed on the console, indicating the value that has been removed and consumed Then, as the queue has been modified, it notifies all other processes so that they will get their chance at performing an action on the concurrent queue In a finally block, we call the unlock() method so we will be sure that, whatever happens in the try block, the lock will be available for other processes to take and use it, avoiding deadlock
      void pushIntoConcurrentQueue(T newValue)
      A method that adds a new value to the end of the queue At first, it tries to acquire the lock; if it succeeds, it tries the following: if the queue is full and no elements can be added at the moment, it awaits in a while loop; once it gets past the while loop (there is now room to add a new value), it calculates the position in which the new element must be inserted and then adds it, increasing afterwards the value of the tail so that it indicates now to the next position in which a value can be inserted A message is printed on the console, indicating the value that has been added Then, as the queue has been modified, it notifies all other processes so that they will get their chance at performing an action on the concurrent queue In a finally block, we call the unlock() method so we will be sure that, whatever happens in the try block, the lock will be available for other processes to take and use it, avoiding deadlock

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

      • head

        private volatile int head
        The current head of our concurrent queue The volatile keyword guarantees that any thread that reads this member will see the most recently written value

      • tail

        private volatile int tail
        The current tail of our concurrent queue The volatile keyword guarantees that any thread that reads this member will see the most recently written value

      • queueValues

        private T[] queueValues
        The generic array that is the actual concurrent queue in which all operations will be performed (values added and then consumed)

      • queueLock

        private java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock queueLock
        An instance of the ReentrantLock -implementation of the Lock interface-, the queueLock is fundamental in ensuring the synchronization of the queue operations performed by the producers and consumers threads

      • queueCondition

        private java.util.concurrent.locks.Condition queueCondition
        A condition variable belonging to the reentrant lock, used in order to perform await(), signal(), signalAll and so on, operations used in order to ensure that we manage with the cases in which the queue is either empty or full

      • queueMaxSize

        private int queueMaxSize
        A member which holds the maximum length of the queue, so the number of elements that can fit inside the queue until it is full

    • Constructor Detail

      • ConcurrentQueue

        public ConcurrentQueue(int queueMaxSize)
        The constructor gets the maximum dimension of the queue; it initialises the head and the tail as being 0, so no element is present in the queue in this moment It creates a new reentrant lock instance and uses its newCondition() method in order to obtain a condition variable; we create a generic queue that will hold a maximum number of queueMaxSize elements; created as an array of Object instances, it is then casted to the generic type T

    • Method Detail

      • pushIntoConcurrentQueue

        public void pushIntoConcurrentQueue(T newValue)
        A method that adds a new value to the end of the queue At first, it tries to acquire the lock; if it succeeds, it tries the following: if the queue is full and no elements can be added at the moment, it awaits in a while loop; once it gets past the while loop (there is now room to add a new value), it calculates the position in which the new element must be inserted and then adds it, increasing afterwards the value of the tail so that it indicates now to the next position in which a value can be inserted A message is printed on the console, indicating the value that has been added Then, as the queue has been modified, it notifies all other processes so that they will get their chance at performing an action on the concurrent queue In a finally block, we call the unlock() method so we will be sure that, whatever happens in the try block, the lock will be available for other processes to take and use it, avoiding deadlock

      • popFromConcurrentQueue

        public T popFromConcurrentQueue()
        A method that removes a value from the head of the queue At first, it tries to acquire the lock; if it succeeds, it tries the following: if the queue is empty and no elements can be removed at the moment, it awaits in a while loop; once it gets past the while loop (there is at least a value in the queue), it calculates the position of the first element (the head index) and then removes it form the queue, increasing afterwards the value of the head so that it indicates now to the next position in which the first valid element can be found A message is printed on the console, indicating the value that has been removed and consumed Then, as the queue has been modified, it notifies all other processes so that they will get their chance at performing an action on the concurrent queue In a finally block, we call the unlock() method so we will be sure that, whatever happens in the try block, the lock will be available for other processes to take and use it, avoiding deadlock

      • getQueueValues

        public T[] getQueueValues()
        A getter method that returns the inner queue used in order to modelate the ConcurrentQueue class

      • isQueueFull

        private boolean isQueueFull()
        A simple boolean method that checks if the queue is full, by verifying if the difference between the tail and the head is equal with the maximum capacity of our queue; if it is not the case, the method returns false

      • isQueueEmpty

        private boolean isQueueEmpty()
        A simple boolean method that checks if the queue is empty, by verifying if the tail is equal with the head (meaining that there are no elements left) if it is not the case, the method returns false
